raw_text: Deterministicmethods for dependency parsing have now been applied to a variety of languages, including Japanese (Kudo and Matsumoto, 2000), English (Yamada and Matsumoto, 2003), Turkish (Oflazer, 2003), and Swedish (Nivre et al, 2004)
clean_text: Deterministic methods for dependency parsing have now been applied to a variety of languages, including Japanese (Kudo and Matsumoto, 2000), English (Yamada and Matsumoto, 2003), Turkish (Oflazer, 2003), and Swedish (Nivre et al, 2004).

raw_text: The parsing methodology investigated here has previously been applied to Swedish, where promising results were obtained with a relatively smalltreebank (approximately 5000 sentences for training), resulting in an attachment score of 84.7% and a labeled accuracy of 80.6% (Nivre et al, 2004) .1 However, since there are no comparable results available for Swedish, it is difficult to assess the significance of these findings, which is one of the reasons why we want to apply the method to a bench mark corpus such as the the Penn Treebank, even though the annotation in this corpus is not ideal for labeled dependency parsing. The paper is structured as follows
clean_text: The parsing methodology investigated here has previously been applied to Swedish, where promising results were obtained with a relatively smalltreebank (approximately 5000 sentences for training), resulting in an attachment score of 84.7% and a labeled accuracy of 80.6% (Nivre et al, 2004).

raw_text: For a more detailed discussion of dependency graphs and well-formedness conditions, the reader is referred to Nivre (2003) .The parsing algorithm used here was first defined for unlabeled dependency parsing in Nivre (2003) and subsequently extended to labeled graph sin Nivre et al (2004)
clean_text: For a more detailed discussion of dependency graphs and well-formedness conditions, the reader is referred to Nivre (2003).

raw_text: Previous work on memory-based learning for deterministic parsing includes Veenstra and Daelemans (2000) and Nivre et al (2004)
clean_text: Previous work on memory-based learning for deterministic parsing includes Veenstra and Daelemans (2000) and Nivre et al (2004).

raw_text: Models similar to model 2 have been found to work well for datasets with a rich annotation of dependency types, such as the Swedish dependency tree bank derived from Einarsson (1976), where the extra part-of-speech features are largely redundant (Nivre et al, 2004)
clean_text: Models similar to model 2 have been found to work well for datasets with a rich annotation of dependency types, such as the Swedish dependency tree bank derived from Einarsson (1976), where the extra part-of-speech features are largely redundant (Nivre et al, 2004).

raw_text: Thesesettings are the result of extensive experiments partially reported in Nivre et al (2004)

clean_text: The portion of words that are assigned the correct head and dependency type (or no head if the word is a root) (Nivre et al, 2004).

raw_text: Memory-based learning (MBL), which is based on the idea that learning is the simple storage of experiences in memory and that solving a new problem is achieved by reusing solutions from similar previously solved problems (Daelemans and Van den Bosch, 2005), has been used primarily by Nivre et al (2004), Nivre and Scholz (2004), and Sagae and Lavie (2005)

citing_paper_authors: Johan, Hall | Joakim, Nivre | Jens, Nilsson
raw_text: Based on results from previous optimization experiments (Nivre et al., 2004), we use the modified value difference metric (MVDM) to determine distances between instances, and distance-weighted class voting for determining the class of a new instance
clean_text: Based on results from previous optimization experiments (Nivre et al., 2004), we use the modified value difference metric (MVDM) to determine distances between instances, and distance-weighted class voting for determining the class of a new instance.

citing_paper_authors: Johan, Hall | Joakim, Nivre | Jens, Nilsson
raw_text: Compared to the state of the art in dependency parsing, the unlabeled attachment scores obtained for Swedish with model? 5, for both MBL and SVM, are about 1 percentage point higher than the results reported for MBL by Nivre et al (2004)
clean_text: Compared to the state of the art in dependency parsing, the unlabeled attachment scores obtained for Swedish with model? 5, for both MBL and SVM, are about 1 percentage point higher than the results reported for MBL by Nivre et al (2004).

raw_text: In the experiments below, we employ a data-driven deterministic dependency parser producing labeled projective dependency graphs,3 previously tested on Swedish (Nivre et al, 2004) and English (Nivre and Scholz, 2004)
clean_text: In the experiments below, we employ a data-driven deterministic dependency parser producing labeled projective dependency graphs,3 previously tested on Swedish (Nivre et al, 2004) and English (Nivre and Scholz, 2004).

raw_text: More details on the memory-based prediction can be found in Nivre et al (2004) and Nivre and Scholz (2004)
clean_text: More details on the memory-based prediction can be found in Nivre et al (2004) and Nivre and Scholz (2004).

raw_text: We focus on Shift-Reduce transition-based parsing proposed by Nivre et al (2004)

To assign probabilities to these actions, previous work has proposed memory-based classifiers (Nivre et al, 2004), SVMs (Nivre et al, 2006b), and Incremental Sigmoid Belief Networks (ISBN) (Titov and Henderson, 2007b)
clean_text: To assign probabilities to these actions, previous work has proposed memory-based classifiers (Nivre et al, 2004), SVMs (Nivre et al, 2006b), and Incremental Sigmoid Belief Networks (ISBN) (Titov and Henderson, 2007b).

raw_text: We build an ISBN model of dependency parsing using the parsing order proposed in (Nivre et al,2004)
clean_text: We build an ISBN model of dependency parsing using the parsing order proposed in (Nivre et al,2004).

raw_text: However, instead of performing deterministic parsing as in (Nivre et al, 2004), we use this ordering to define a generative history-based model, by integrating word prediction operations into theset of parser actions
clean_text: However, instead of performing deterministic parsing as in (Nivre et al, 2004), we use this ordering to define a generative history-based model, by integrating word prediction operations into the set of parser actions.

raw_text: Another advantage of generative models is that they do not suffer from the label bias problems (Bottou, 1991), which is a potential problem for conditional or deterministic history-based models, such as (Nivre et al, 2004)
clean_text: Another advantage of generative models is that they do not suffer from the label bias problems (Bottou, 1991), which is a potential problem for conditional or deterministic history-based models, such as (Nivre et al, 2004).
